name: diapason
content:
diapason noun
(MUSIC)
Add to word list
Add to word list
[ C ]
  music
  specialized one of two main stops (= sets of pipes) of a pipe organ: The pipes play with open, stopped, and double diapason. One of the largest and most fundamental diapasons, or sets of pipes, was given away.
[ C ]
  music
  specialized a musical sound that suddenly gets louder, like the sound of an organ: The hymn rose in a swelling diapason.
[ C ]
  music
  specialized the range of sounds or notes made by something: Each trickle contributes its tiny warble to the diapason of the waterfall.
[ C ]
  music
  specialized a
tuning fork

More examplesFewer examplesThis organ incorporates parts of the original organ and also a pedal open diapason given as a gift to the church.The organ swelled in a muted diapason, soon dropping to an almost inaudible tone. The shattering symphonies or dying murmurs of the organ suggested the rushing of the wind through the forest, then the full diapason of the storm. The forks are tuned to a Diapason normal, also called low pitch or French pitch.
